review.title: The Natural Stories Corpus
review.abstract: It is now a common practice to compare models of human language processing by predicting participant reactions (such as reading times) to corpora consisting of rich naturalistic linguistic materials. However, many of the corpora used in these studies are based on naturalistic text and thus do not contain many of the low-frequency syntactic constructions that are often required to distinguish processing theories. Here we describe a new corpus consisting of English texts edited to contain many low-frequency syntactic constructions while still sounding fluent to native speakers. The corpus is annotated with hand-corrected parse trees and includes self-paced reading time data. Here we give an overview of the content of the corpus and release the data.

metadata.title: The Natural Stories Corpus

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Dependent variables collected via fixed corpora include word fixation time in eye tracking (Kennedy et al., 2003), word response time in1Available by http: / / github.com / languageMIT / naturalstories. This corpus is licensed under a Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike (CC BY-NC-SA) license that allows free modification and redistribution of the corpus as long as derivative work is released under the same terms. Xiv: 170 8.05 763v 1 [cs.C L] 1self-paced reading (Roark et al., 2009; Frank et al., 2013), BOLD in fMRI data.

sections.heading: 2 Related Work
sections.text: Data sets are collected here that are commonly used to test psycholinguistic theories and how they relate to the current publication. Currently, the most prominent psycholinguistic corpus for English is the Dundee Corpus (Kennedy et al., 2003), which contains 51,501 word marks in 2,368 sentences from British newspaper editorials, along with eye-tracking data from 10 participants. A dependency analysis of the corpus is performed in Barrett et al. As in the current work, the eye-tracking data in the Dundee corpus is collected for sentences in context, reflecting influences beyond the sentence level. The corpus has experienced widespread adoption, see Demberg and Keller (2010); Mitchell et al. (2011); Fossum and Levy (2012); Smith and Levy (2013); van Schijndel and Schuler.

sections.heading: 3 Corpus Description
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 3.1 Text
sections.text: The Corpus Natural Stories consists of 10 stories containing 10,245 lexical word marks for a total of 485 sentences. The stories were developed by A.V., E.F., E.G., and S.P. by evaluating and editing existing publicly available texts to use many subject and object extracted relative clauses, columns, topicalized structures, extrapolated relative clauses, penalty points, sentence complements, local structural ambiguities (especially NP / Z ambiguities), idioms, and related clauses with a variety of coherence relationships. The original texts are in Table 1. The mean number of lexical words per sentence is 21.1, roughly the same as the Dundee corpus (21.7). Figure 1 shows a histogram of sentence length in Natural Stories compared to Dundee. The word and sentence count for each story in Table 1. The number of lexical words per sentence is 21.1, roughly the same as the length of the Dundee corpus (1.7).

sections.heading: 3.2 Parses
sections.text: Texts were automatically analyzed with the Stanford parser (Klein and Manning, 2003) and corrected by hand. Trace comments were added by hand. We provide the resulting Penn Treebank-like phrase structure analysis trees. We also offer Universal Dependencies Parses (Nivre, 2015), which are automatically converted from the corrected parse trees with the Stanford parser.

sections.heading: 3.3 Self-Paced Reading Data
sections.text: SPR data was collected for the stories of 181 native English speakers on Amazon Mechanical Turk (Just et al., 1982), which were presented in a dashed, movable storefront; the spaces were masked; each participant read 5 stories per HIT; 19 participants read all 10 stories, and 3 participants stopped after one story; each story was accompanied by 6 comprehension questions; and we discarded SPR data from a participant's run through a story if the participant correctly asked fewer than 5 questions (89 stories passed through).

sections.heading: 3.3.1 Inter-Subject Correlations
sections.text: To evaluate the reliability of the self-reading RTs and their robustness among the subjects, we analyzed the correlation between each subject. For each subject, we correlated the Spearman correlation of the RTs of that subject to a story with the average RTs of all other subjects to that story. Thus, for each story, we obtain one ISC statistic per subject. Figure 4 shows histograms of these statistics per story.

sections.heading: 3.3.2 Psycholinguistic Sanity Checks
sections.text: To validate our RT data, we investigated whether the known effects of frequency, word length, and surprise value (Hale, 2001; Levy, 2008; Smith and Levy, 2013) had an effect on RTs. To do this, for each of the three predictors log frequency, log trigram probability, and word length, we fit a linear mixed-effect regression model with subject and history as random intercepts (models with random slopes did not converge) predicting RT. Frequency and trigram probabilities were calculated from Google Books N-gram and add up over years from 1990 to 2013. (These counts are also published with this data set.) Results of regressions are presented in Table 3; we report on the results of the maximum convergence model. In accordance with well-known ef effects, both increased frequency and increased probability lead to faster reading times, and word length to slower reading times.

sections.heading: 3.4 Syntactic Constructions
sections.text: Here we give an overview of the low frequency or marked syntactical constructions that occur in the stories. We coded sentences in the Natural Stories corpus for the presence of a number of marked constructions, and also coded 200 randomly selected sentences from the Dundee corpus for the same characteristics. The coded features are listed and explained in Appendix A. Figure 5 shows the frequency of these marked constructions per sentence in the two corpus. The figure shows that the natural stories exhibit a particularly high rate of non-local VP conjunction, non-strictive SRCs, idioms, adjective conjunction, non-canonical ORCs, local NP / S ambiguities, and columns.

sections.heading: 4 Conclusion
sections.text: We have described a new psycholinguistic corpus of English, consisting of edited naturalistic text that contains many rare or difficult-to-process constructions while still sounding fluent. We believe that this corpus will be an important part of a series of test sets for psycholinguistic models that reveal their behavior in unusual constructions in ways that fully naturalistic corpus cannot. We also hope that the corpus described here will form the basis for further data collection and annotation.

sections.heading: Acknowledgments
sections.text: This work was supported by the NSF DDRI Grant # 1551543 to R.F., NSF Fellowships # 0844472 and # 1534318 to E.G., and the NIH Career Development Award HD057522 to E.F. The authors thank the following people: Laura Stearns for checking and correcting the parses by hand, Suniyya Waraich for helping with syntactic coding, Cory Shain and Marten van Schijndel for the annotations by hand, and Kyle Mahowald for helping with initial exploratory analysis of the SPR data. In addition, the authors thank Nancy Kanwisher for recording half of the stories (the other half was recorded by E.G.), Wade Shen for the initial alignment between the audio files and the texts, and Jeanne Gallee for correcting the alignment by hand.

sections.heading: A Features coded for Section 3.4
sections.text: Characteristics encoded are: • Local / non-local VP clause: Connection of VPs in which the header verbs are adjacent (local) or not adjacent (non-local) • Sentential conjunction: Connection of VPs with explicit quantifiers. • Restrictive / non-restrictive SRC: Subject-extracted relative clauses with either restrictive or non-restrictive semantics. • Sentential conjunction: Connection of CPs with explicit semantics. • No-relativizer ORC: An object-extracted relative clauses with either restrictive or non-restrictive semantics.

Many of the most puzzling phenomena in psycholinguistics, and the phenomena which have been used to test models, have only been observed in extremely rare constructions, such as multiply nested preverbal relative clauses (Gibson and Thomas, 1999; Grodner and Gibson, 2005; Vasishth et al., 2010).

Currently the most prominent psycholinguistic corpus for English is the Dundee Corpus (Kennedy et al., 2003), which contains 51,501 word tokens in 2,368 sentences from British newspaper editorials, along with eyetracking data from 10 participants.
The Potsdam Sentence Corpus (Kliegl et al., 2006) of German provides 1138 words in 144 sentences, with cloze probabilities and eyetracking data for each word.

The UCL Corpus (Frank et al., 2013) consists of 361 English sentences drawn from amateur novels, chosen for their ability to be understood out of context, with self-paced reading and eyetracking data.

The corpus has been used to evaluate models of sentence processing based on dependency parsing (Boston et al., 2008, 2011) and to study effects of predictability on event-related potentials (Dambacher et al., 2006). The MIT Corpus introduced in Bachrach et al. (ms) has similar aims to the current work, collecting reading time and fMRI data over sentences designed to contain varied structures. This dataset consists of four narratives with a total of 2647 tokens; it has been used to evaluate models of incremental prediction in Roark et al. (2009), Wu et al.

metadata.abstractText: It is now a common practice to compare models of human language processing by predicting participant reactions (such as reading times) to corpora consisting of rich naturalistic linguistic materials. However, many of the corpora used in these studies are based on naturalistic text and thus do not contain many of the low-frequency syntactic constructions that are often required to distinguish processing theories. Here we describe a new corpus consisting of English texts edited to contain many low-frequency syntactic constructions while still sounding fluent to native speakers. The corpus is annotated with hand-corrected parse trees and includes self-paced reading time data. Here we give an overview of the content of the corpus and release the data.1
